revisions.rev:
{{Infobox person | image = JamesFrancoOct2011.jpg | caption = Franco in October 2011 | birthname = James Edward Franco | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1978|4|19}} | birth_place = [[Palo Alto, California]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, director, author,singer, screenwriter, producer, instructor, painter, pilot, model, musician | yearsactive = 1997âpresent }} '''James Edward Franco''' (born April 19, 1978) is an American actor, film director, producer, screenwriter, author, painter, performance artist and instructor at [[New York University]]. He left college in order to pursue acting and started off his career by making guest appearances on television series in the 1990s. Franco landed a lead part on the short-lived [[cult hit]] television program ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'' and later achieved recognition for playing the titular character in the TV biographical film ''[[James Dean (film)|James Dean]]'' (2001), for which he was awarded a [[Golden Globe Award]]. He achieved international fame with his portrayals of [[Harry Osborn]] in [[Sam Raimi]]'s [[Spider-Man in film|''Spider-Man'' trilogy]].
Franco is critically acclaimed as an actor. He has done both dramatic and comedic work in projects and has appeared in an eclectic range of films since the 2000s, ranging from [[period film|period]] to contemporary pieces, and from major [[Hollywood]] productions to less publicized [[independent film|indie films]], as well as [[fantasy film]]s to [[biographical film|biopics]] and [[soap opera]]s. Other notable films include ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]'', a 2008 [[stoner comedy]] that earned him his second Golden Globes nomination; the 2008 [[Harvey Milk]]-biopic ''[[Milk (film)|Milk]]''; and [[Danny Boyle]]'s 2010 [[drama film]] ''[[127 Hours]]'', about real-life mountain climber [[Aron Ralston]]'s struggle to free his hand from a boulder. His performance in ''127 Hours'' earned him nominations for many high-profile awards, including the Academy Awards, Golden Globe and [[Screen Actors Guild Award]]s. In 2011, he starred opposite [[Andy Serkis]] in [[Rupert Wyatt]]'s successful [[science fiction film]] ''[[Rise of the Planet of the Apes]]'', a [[reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the [[Planet of the Apes (franchise)|''Planet of the Apes'' franchise]].
Franco has hosted ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' twice as well as the [[83rd Academy Awards]] with [[Anne Hathaway (actress)|Anne Hathaway]]. He volunteers for the Art of Elysium charity. Franco currently teaches a class at [[New York University]] about transferring poetry to film.<ref name=francoNYUCourse>{{cite news|last=Rathe|first=Adam|title=James Franco, NYU professor, reveals details of his class; Students will transfer poetry to film|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2011/08/03/2011-08-03_james_franco_nyu_professor_reveals_details_of_his_class_.html|accessdate=4 August 2011|newspaper=NY Daily News|date=4 August 2011}}</ref>
== Early life and family == Nicknamed "Ted", James Edward Franco was born in [[Palo Alto, California]]. His mother, Betsy Lou (nÃ©e Verne), is a poet, author, and editor, and his father, Douglas Eugene "Doug" Franco (1948-2011),<ref>http://www.eonline.com/news/james_francos_father_dies_63/267576</ref> ran a non-profit agency and a shipping container company. The two met as students at [[Stanford University]].{{r|anderson20100725}}<ref name=enidro>{{cite web|last=Wolfson|first=Jill|title=Penciling in a Career|publisher=Stanford Magazine|date=September/October 2009|url=http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/2009/sepoct/show/franco.html|accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name=ohwohw>{{Cite book|last=Marquis Who's Who, Inc|title=Who's who of emerging leaders in America|publisher=Marquis Who's Who|year=1991|url=|isbn=0837972027}}</ref> Franco's father was of [[Portuguese American|Portuguese]] and [[Swedish American|Swedish]] descent<ref name="review">{{cite web | title=LatinoReview.com | work=Franco Talks Annapolis! | url=http://www.latinoreview.com/news.php?id=217 | accessdate=May 9, 2006|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060614050041/http://www.latinoreview.com/news.php?id=217 |archivedate = June 14, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref> and Franco's mother is [[History of the Jews in Russia|Jewish]], a descendant of immigrants from [[Russia]] (her family's surname had been changed from "Verovitz" to "Verne").<ref name="bostonref1">{{cite news|last=Rhone|first=Paysha|title=Spidey foe meets his match in Harvard's Hasty Pudding crew|work=Boston Globe|date=February 14, 2009|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/celebrity/articles/2009/02/14/spidey_foe_meets_his_match_in_harvard_hasty_pudding_crew/|accessdate=August 9, 2009}}</ref><ref name=rai/> His paternal grandmother, Marjorie (Peterson) Franco, is a published author of [[young-adult fiction|young adult]] books;<ref name=ohwohw/><ref name=hcrela>{{Cite book|last=Commire|first=Anne|coauthors=Gale Research Company|title=Something about the Author, Volume 38|publisher=Gale Research|year=1985|page=77|url=|isbn=0810300710}}</ref> his maternal grandmother, Mitzie (Levine) Verne, owns the Verne Art Gallery, a prominent art gallery in [[Cleveland]], and was an active member in the [[National Council of Jewish Women]].<ref name=wehida>{{Cite news|last=Spevack|first=Violet|title=Cavalcade|publisher=Cleveland Jewish News|date=January 31, 2002|url=http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/articles/2002/01/31//export10620.txt|accessdate=December 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name=wehidareb>{{Cite news|last=Spevack|first=Violet|title=Cavalcade 10/23|publisher=Cleveland Jewish News|date=October 23, 2009|url=http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/articles/2009/11/13/features/cavalcade/doc4ae081106974b082383090.txt|accessdate=December 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://admission.case.edu/admissions/news/news_story.asp?iNewsID=249&strBack=/admissions/news/news_archive.asp|title=Case Western Reserve University|accessdate=August 8, 2008|publisher=Admission Case |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071024200830/http://admission.case.edu/admissions/news/news_story.asp?iNewsID=249&strBack=/admissions/news/news_archive.asp |archivedate = October 24, 2007}}</ref>
Franco's family upbringing was "academic, liberal and largely secular."<ref name=niadraug>{{Cite news|last=Raphael|first=Amy|title=Acting clever|work=The Guardian |location=UK ||date=January 24, 2009|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2009/jan/24/james-franco-interview-milk|accessdate=May 1, 2011}}</ref> He grew up in California with his two younger brothers, Tom and [[Dave Franco|Dave]] ("Davy"), the latter of whom is also an actor.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/james-franco/|title=James Franco|last=Van Sant|first=Gus|work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]|page=1|accessdate=March 2, 2009}}</ref> Talented at mathematics, Franco interned at [[Lockheed Martin]].<ref name="anderson20100725">Anderson, Sam. "[http://instapaperstories.tumblr.com/post/972880219/the-james-franco-project-new-york-magazine The James Franco Project]" ''New York'', July 25, 2010.</ref> Franco was often encouraged by his father to get good grades and did exceptionally well on his [[SAT]]s.<ref name=niadraug/> He graduated from [[Palo Alto High School]] in 1996, where he acted in plays.{{r|anderson20100725}}<ref name="Yahoo">{{cite web|url=http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800352352/bio|title=James Franco Biography|accessdate=August 8, 2008|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref> In his high school years, Franco was arrested for underage drinking, graffiti and for being a part of a group that stole designer fragrances from department stores and sold them to classmates.<ref name="10facts"/> These arrests led to him briefly becoming a [[ward of the state]]. Facing the possibility of [[juvenile hall]], a judge decided to give Franco a second chance.<ref name="itas"/> "It was teen angst. I was uncomfortable in my own skin. I was shy. I changed my ways just in time to get good grades", he recalled of his troubles with the law.<ref name=niadraug/>
Although the idea of becoming a [[marine zoologist]] interested him, Franco had always secretly wanted to become an actor but feared rejection.<ref name="itas"/> He enrolled at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA) as an English major,<ref>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Posner|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080805.wpineapple05/BNStory/Entertainment/?page=rss&id=RTGAM.20080805.wpineapple05|title=Top of the food chain|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=August 5, 2008|work=The Globe and Mail |location=Canada }}</ref> but dropped out after his freshman year against his parents' wishes{{r|anderson20100725}} to pursue a career as an actor, since he would have to have waited two years to audition for their acting program.<ref name="itas"/> Franco instead chose to take acting lessons with Robert Carnegie at the Playhouse West.<ref name="Yahoo"/> Around this time, Franco took up a late-night job at [[McDonald's]] to support himself since his parents refused to do so. He was a vegetarian until working there.<ref name="10facts"/> While working at the establishment, for his acting classes, he would practice accents on customers.<ref name="itas">"James Franco" [[Inside the Actors Studio]] December 7, 2010</ref> Knowing that the aspiring actor was doing his best to follow his passion, Carnegie poignantly told Franco to pay him what he could and later on pay him back.<ref name="itas"/>
== Acting career == === Early work === After 15 months of training, he began auditioning in Los Angeles, and started professionally acting in 1997 with guest roles on television shows. His first break came in 1999, after he was cast in a leading role on the short-lived but well-reviewed television series ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shoutfactory.com/browse/31/freaks_and_geeks.aspx|title=Shout! Factory â Freaks And Geeks|accessdate=August 8, 2008|publisher=Shout Factory}}</ref> The program, which ran for 18 episodes and was canceled due to low viewership, later became a [[cult hit]] among audiences.<ref>{{cite web |url= |title=IFC picks up two Judd Apatow series |work=Hollywood Reporter |author=Guider, Elizabeth |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=April 30, 2011}}</ref> He has since described the series as "one of the most fun" work experiences that he has had.<ref name="upi">{{cite web | title=United Press International | work=Franco to reunite with Freaks pals | url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20060923-111422-3997r | accessdate=September 23, 2006|publisher=United Press International}}</ref> In another interview, Franco said: "When we were doing ''Freaks and Geeks'', I didnât quite understand how movies and TV worked, and I would improvise even if the camera wasnât on me ... So I was improvising a little bit back then, but not in a productive way."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/james-franco/4/|title=James Franco|last=Van Sant|first=Gus|work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]|page=4|accessdate=March 3, 2009}}</ref> Franco made his film debut in a brief role in the 1999 Drew Barrymore-starring ''[[Never Been Kissed]]'' and his first major movie was the romantic teen comedy ''[[Whatever It Takes (film)|Whatever It Takes]]'' (2000), in which he played popular jock Chris. The latter is a modern day remake of the 1897 play ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac]]''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Owen|last=Gleiberman|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,64610,00.html|title=What It Takes Review|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=March 31, 2000|work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=A.O.|last=Scott|url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9C06E5DA143DF937A15750C0A9669C8B63|title=Whatever It Takes Review|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=March 24, 2000|work=New York Times}}</ref>
He was subsequently cast as the [[James Dean|title role]] in director [[Mark Rydell]]'s 2001 TV biographical film ''[[James Dean (film)|James Dean]]''.<ref name="jdusatoday">{{cite news|first=Kelly|last=Carter|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/television/2001-07-27-james-franco.htm|title=James Franco: The next James Dean|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=July 27, 2001|work=USA Today}}</ref><ref name="latimes">{{cite news|first=Chris|last=Lee|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/aug/06/entertainment/et-franco7|title=James Franco plays against type in 'Pineapple Express'|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=August 6, 2008|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> To immerse himself in the role, Franco went from being a non-smoker to smoking two packs of cigarettes a day, dyed his dark brown hair blond, and learned to ride a motorcycle as well as play guitar and the bongos.<ref name="jdusatoday"/> To have a greater understanding of Dean, Franco spent hours with two of Dean's associates. Other research included reading books on Dean and studying his movies.<ref name="jdusatoday"/> While filming ''James Dean'', the actor, to get into character, cut off communication with his family and friends, as well as his then-girlfriend. "It was a very lonely existence," he notes. "If I wasn't on a set, I was watching James Dean. That was my whole thinking. James Dean. James Dean."<ref name="jdusatoday"/> Despite already being a fan of Dean, Franco feared he might be typecast if he'd captured the actor too convincingly. Ken Tucker of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote: "Franco could have walked through the role and done a passable Dean, but instead gets under the skin of this insecure, rootless young man."<ref>{{cite web|first=Ken|last=Tucker|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,255462,00.html|title=James Dean TV Review|accessdate=August 13, 2008|date=August 3, 2001|work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> He received a [[Golden Globe Award]] and nominations for an [[Emmy Award]] and a [[Screen Actors Guild|Screen Actors Guild Award]] (SAG).<ref name="golden globe">{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/browse/member/29141|title=HFPA â Awards Search|accessdate=August 8, 2008|publisher=Golden Globes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=8th Annual SAG Awards Nominee â Screen Actors Guild Awards|accessdate=August 8, 2008|publisher=Screen Actors Guild Awards}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=2002 Emmys|accessdate=August 8, 2008|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
=== 2002â2007=== [[File:James Franco 2007 Spiderman 3 premiere.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Franco at the ''[[Spider-Man 3]]'' premiere, April 2007]] Franco achieved worldwide fame and attention, in the 2002 superhero film ''[[Spider-Man (film)|Spider-Man]]'', when he played [[Harry Osborn]], the son of the villainous [[Green Goblin]] ([[Willem Dafoe]]) and best friend of the [[Spider-Man|title character]] ([[Tobey Maguire]]). Originally, Franco was considered for the lead role of [[Spider-Man|Spider-Man/Peter Parker]] in the film,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2002/2002-05-03-spider-man.htm#more | title=Mike Clark review |work=USA Today | date=May 3, 2002 | accessdate=January 23, 2007}}</ref> though the lead went to Maguire. Todd McCarthy of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' noted that there are "good moments" between Maguire and Franco in the film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=review&reviewid=VE1117917507&categoryid=31&cs=1|title=Spider-Man Review|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|date=April 19, 2002|work=Variety |accessdate=March 2, 2009}}</ref> ''Spider-Man'' was a commercial and critical success.<ref name="rt"/> The movie grossed $114 million during its opening weekend in North America and went on to earn $822 million worldwide.<ref name="earnings">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Actor&id=jamesfranco.htm|title=James Franco Movie Box Office Results|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=March 2, 2009}}</ref> He next starred in ''[[Sonny (film)|Sonny]]'', a 2002 release in which he was directed by fellow actor [[Nicolas Cage]]. It was Cage's involvement that had attracted Franco to the film.<ref name="2002about">{{cite web |url=http://movies.about.com/library/weekly/aasonnyintb.htm |title=James Franco Talks About "Sonny" |author=Murray, Rebecca; Topel Fred |publisher=[[About.com]] |accessdate=April 28, 2011}}</ref> Set in 1980s New Orleans, ''Sonny'' follows the titular character (Franco) returning home after just being discharged from the Army. To prepare for his role, he met with sex workers or people who had previously been prostitutes.<ref name="2002about"/> The movie was panned by critics, with the ''[[New York Post]]''s Lou Lumenick calling it an "instant candidate for worst movie of the year."<ref>{{cite news |title=Sonny |first=Lou |last=Lumenick |work=New York Post |date=December 27, 2002 |accessdate=April 28, 2011}}</ref> Franco was cast as a homeless drug addict in the drama ''[[City by the Sea]]'' (2002) after co-star [[Robert De Niro]] saw a snippet of his work in ''James Dean''.<ref name="jdusatoday"/> He lived on the streets for several days to better understand the subject of the matter<ref>{{cite web |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/370/370015p1.html |title=An Interview with James Franco |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=IGN Entertainment |author=B., Scotty |date=September 4, 2002 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> as well as talk to former or still using drug addicts.<ref name="2002about"/> Both projects were released in September.
Following ''City by the Sea'', he co-starred alongside [[Neve Campbell]] in [[Robert Altman]]'s ballet movie ''[[The Company (film)|The Company]]'' (2003).<ref name=niadraug/> The success of the first ''Spider-Man'' film led Franco to reprise the role in the 2004 sequel, ''[[Spider-Man 2]]''. The movie was well received by critics,<ref name="rt"/> and it proved to be a big financial success, setting a new opening weekend box office record for North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=spiderman2.htm|title=Spider-Man 2 (2004)|date=June 30, 2004|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=December 9, 2008}}</ref> With revenue of $783 million worldwide, it became the second highest grossing film in 2004.<ref name="earnings"/> The following year he made and starred in the [[black comedy]] ''The Ape''<ref name=niadraug/> and the 2005 [[war film]] ''[[The Great Raid]]'', in which he portrayed [[Robert Prince (captain)|Robert Prince]], a captain in the United States Army's elite [[6th Ranger Battalion|Sixth Ranger Battalion]]. In 2006, Franco co-starred with [[Tyrese Gibson]] in ''[[Annapolis (film)|Annapolis]]'' and played legendary hero [[Tristan]] in ''[[Tristan & Isolde (film)|Tristan & Isolde]]'', a [[period piece]] dramatization of the [[Tristan and Iseult]] story also starring English actress [[Sophia Myles]]. For the former, he did eight months of boxing training and for the latter, he practiced horseback riding and sword fighting.<ref name="127facts">{{cite web |url=http://blog.moviefone.com/2010/11/02/james-franco-facts/ |title='127' Facts About James Franco |first=Kim |last=Potts |work=[[Moviefone]] |publisher=AOL Inc |date=November 2, 2010 |publisher=March 6, 2011}}</ref> He then completed training for his [[Private Pilot Licence]] in preparation for his role in ''[[Flyboys (film)|Flyboys]]'',<ref name="10facts">{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1540514,00.html |title=10 Things You Don't Know About James Franco |first=Lindsay |last=Soll |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=September 29, 2006 |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> which was released in September 2006; the same month, Franco appeared briefly in ''[[The Wicker Man (2006 film)|The Wicker Man]]'', the remake of the [[The Wicker Man (1973 film)|seminal horror film]]. Also in 2006, he made a [[cameo appearance]] in the romantic comedy ''[[The Holiday]]''.<ref name="latimes"/>
He again played Harry Osborn in ''[[Spider-Man 3]]'' (2007). In contrast to the previous two films' positive reviews, ''Spider-Man 3'' was met with a mixed reception by critics.<ref name="rt"/> Nonetheless, with a total worldwide gross of $891 million, it stands as the most successful [[Spider-Man in film#Box office performance|film in the series]], and Franco's highest grossing film to date.<ref name="earnings"/> In this same year, Franco made a cameo appearance as himself in the Apatow-directed comedy ''[[Knocked Up]]'', which starred ''Freaks and Geeks'' alumni [[Seth Rogen]], [[Jason Segel]] and [[Martin Starr]].<ref name="10facts"/> Franco co-starred with [[Sienna Miller]] in the low-budget [[independent films]] ''[[Camille (2007 film)|Camille]]'', a dark fantasy [[dramedy]] about a young newly wed couple and ''[[Interview (2007 film)|Interview]]'', where he appears in a voice only role, both 2007 movies that were ignored by audiences and critics alike. Among his other 2007 projects were ''Good Time Max'', which Franco wrote, directed and starred in. The movie premiered at the 2007 [[Tribeca Film Festival]] and centers around two talented brothers who take very diverse paths in life, one going on to become a doctor whilst the other sibling (Franco) experiences unemployment and uses drugs. The actor chose to cast himself in that role because, "It was really just a process of elimination. I was better suited for this role than the responsible surgeon."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huffpost-coverage/james-franco-is-good-time_b_47234.html |title=James Franco is Good Time Max |work=Huffington Post |location=USA |publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com Inc |first=Katherine |last=Thomson |date=April 30, 2007 |accessdate=April 28, 2011}}</ref>
=== 2008â2010 === He next starred in ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]'' (2008), a stoner comedy co-starring and co-written by Rogen and produced by Apatow.<ref name="upi" /><ref>{{cite web|first=Peter|last=Travers|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/15138038/review/21896158/pineapple_express|title=Pineapple Express Review|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=August 7, 2008|work=Rolling Stone|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080822110043/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/15138038/review/21896158/pineapple_express |archivedate = August 22, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Of Franco's character, Apatow said, "You tell him, 'Okay, you're going to play a pot dealer,' and he comes back with a three-dimensional character you totally believe exists. He takes it very seriously, even when it's comedy."<ref name="TimeLine">{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/james_franco/biography|title=James Franco Timeline|work=People|last=Mock|first=Janet|accessdate=January 8, 2011}}</ref> In her ''[[New York Times]]'' review, critic Manohla Dargis wrote: "Heâs delightful as Saul, loosey-goosey and goofy yet irrepressibly sexy, despite that greasy curtain of hair and a crash pad with a zero WAF (Woman Acceptance Factor). Itâs an unshowy, generous performance and it greatly humanizes a movie that, as it shifts genre gears and cranks up the noise, becomes disappointingly sober and self-serious."<ref>{{cite news|first=Manohla|last=Dargis|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/06/movies/06pine.html|title='Pineapple Express' â Stoners Who Put the Bud in Buddies|accessdate=August 24, 2008|date=August 6, 2008|work=New York Times}}</ref> His performance earned him a second [[Golden Globe]] nomination, for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor â Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor in a Musical or Comedy]].<ref name="golden globe"/> He has stated in some interviews that he no longer uses [[cannabis]] (although he has occasionally alluded to his smoking marijuana, most notably during an extended segment on ''[[The Colbert Report]]''.<ref>http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/380446/april-05-2011/james-franco-pt--2</ref>) He was awarded ''[[High Times]]'' magazine's Stoner of the Year Award for his work in ''Pineapple Express''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Steven|last=Hager|url=http://hightimes.com/video/hager/4693|title=Franco's First Time|accessdate=January 4, 2010|date=September 30, 2008|work=[[High Times]]}}</ref> In 2008 he also appeared in two films by American artist [[Carter (artist)|Carter]], exhibited at the Yvon Lambert gallery in Paris.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2009-04-07-james-franco_N.htm|title=Franco takes 'Erased James Franco' to art|last=Freydkin|first=Donna|date=April 7, 2009|work=USA Today|accessdate=April 22, 2009}}</ref> On September 20, 2008, he hosted the sketch comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (''SNL''),<ref>{{cite news|title="Saturday Night Live" with James Franco improves in week two, but still far from its peak|last=Boedeker|first=Hal|date=September 21, 2008|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|accessdate=September 21, 2008}}</ref> and a second time on December 19, 2009.<ref>{{cite news|first=Soraya|last=Roberts|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2009/12/20/2009-12-20_james_franco_hosts_saturday_night_live_pulls_an_adam_lambert_with_manonman_kiss.html|title=James Franco hosts 'Saturday Night Live': Actor pulls an Adam Lambert with man-on-man kiss|accessdate=December 22, 2009|date=December 20, 2009|work=[[Daily News (New York)]]}}</ref>
Franco starred opposite [[Sean Penn]], [[Josh Brolin]], and [[Emile Hirsch]] in [[Gus Van Sant]]'s ''[[Milk (film)|Milk]]'' (2008).<ref>{{cite news|first=Donna|last=Freydkin|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-08-03-james-franco_N.htm|title='Pineaple' star Franco digs deep, plays stoner and serious|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=August 3, 2008|work=USA Today}}</ref> In the film, he played [[Scott Smith (activist)|Scott Smith]], the boyfriend of [[Harvey Milk]] (Penn). [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', in review of the film, wrote: "Franco is a nice match for him [Penn] as the lover who finally has enough of political life."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/la-et-milk26-2008nov26,0,1941714.story|title=Review: 'Milk'|last=Turan|first=Kenneth|date=November 26, 2008|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=February 23, 2009}} {{dead link| date=June 2010 | bot=DASHBot}}</ref> For his performance in the film, Franco won the [[Independent Spirit Award]] in the category for [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Male|Best Supporting Actor]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7904366.stm|title=Rourke steals Spirit award show|last=Smith|first=Neil|date=February 22, 2009|work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 23, 2009|quote=Other acting awards went to Melissa Leo and Penelope Cruz, both of whom are also up for Oscars, and to James Franco for his supporting role in ''Milk''.}}</ref> In late 2009, he joined the cast of the daytime soap opera ''[[General Hospital]]'' on a recurring basis. He plays [[Franco (General Hospital)|Franco]], a [[multimedia artist]] much like himself,{{r|anderson20100725}} who comes to [[Port Charles]] with unfinished business with mob enforcer [[Jason Morgan (General Hospital)|Jason Morgan]] ([[Steve Burton (actor)|Steve Burton]]).<ref>{{cite news|first=Adam|last=Bryant|title=James Franco to Appear on General Hospital|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Franco-General-Hospital-1010386.aspx|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=October 1, 2009|accessdate=October 1, 2009}}</ref> Franco has called his ''General Hospital'' role [[performance art]]. In March 2011, he will reprise his role in two episodes of ''General Hospital''.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tvguide.com/News/Exclusive-James-Franco-1026519.aspx|title= Exclusive: James Franco Heads Back to General Hospital|publisher=TVGuide.com|accessdate=December 8, 2010}}</ref> In September 2011, Franco will reprise his role as [[Franco (General Hospital)|Robert "Franco" Frank]] for an extended stay.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.soapcentral.com/gh/news/2011/0725-franco.php|title=Franco to return to GH.|last=|first=|date=July 25, 2011|work=|publisher=SoapCentral|accessdate=July 25, 2011|quote=}}</ref>
2010 was a prolific year for Franco. He kicked off the year by making an appearance on the sitcom ''[[30 Rock]]'' where he played himself and carried on a fake romance with [[Jenna Maroney]] ([[Jane Krakowski]]) in a scheme concocted by their respective agents.<ref>{{cite news|first=Kate|last=Stanhope|title=James Franco to Guest-Star on ''30 Rock''|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Franco-30-Rock-1011547.aspx|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=November 3, 2009|accessdate=November 5, 2009}}</ref> After appearing in the commercial successes ''[[Date Night]]'', an action comedy, and ''[[Eat Pray Love]]'', an adaption of a self-help novel, Franco played poet [[Allen Ginsberg]] in the drama ''[[Howl (film)|Howl]]'', released on September 24.<ref name=rai>{{Cite news|last=Ganahl|first=Jane|title=Howl's Cast and Crew On the Road to Sundance|publisher=Vanity Fair|date=January 23, 2010|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2010/01/howl-cast-and-crew-on-the-road-to-sundance.html|accessdate=October 15, 2010}}</ref> The latter, about his most known poem and the trial about the work, premiered at the [[Berlin Film Festival]] and earned modest reviews.<ref name="rt"/>
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |salign=center |quote ="I didn't have many actors to act opposite with. So the crew and the director and the writer, they all became my co-stars in a way and we all had this one character to share in. I, it was my body but we were all kinda jammed in there [the gully]. |source = Franco on filming ''127 Hours''<ref name="isa"/> |width = 30% |align = right }}
His next project was ''[[127 Hours]]'', directed by Academy Award winner [[Danny Boyle]], where Franco portrayed real-life mountain climber [[Aron Ralston]]. It was given a limited release starting on November 5, 2010.<ref name="bom"/> ''127 Hours'' centered on Ralston trying to free his hand after it became trapped under a boulder in a ravine while canyoneering alone in [[Utah]] and resorting to desperate measures in order to survive, eventually amputating his arm. During the five-week, 12-hours-per-day shoot, Franco would only leave the gully set to use the lavatory and would read books such as academic textbooks to keep busy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/starsandstories/8209459/A-class-apart-interview-with-James-Franco.html |title=A class apart: interview with James Franco |first=Tom |last=Shone |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=January 4, 2011 |accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref> Franco later called making ''127 Hours'' a once in a life time experience.<ref name="isa">2011 [[Independent Spirit Awards]]</ref> To date, ''127 Hours'' is one of his most well-reviewed movies<ref name="rt">{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/celebrity/james_franco/| title=James Franco |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=Flixster, Inc |accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref> and was also a commercial success, commissioning $57.5 million against an $18 million budget.<ref name="bom">{{cite news |title=127 Hours |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=IMDB.com Inc |accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref> His performance earned him universal acclaim from critics. Subsequently, he was nominated for most of the high-profile awards, notably an [[Academy Award]], Golden Globe and SAG as well as winning an Independent Spirit Award.
=== 2011âpresent === On February 23, Franco made a cameo appearance on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Minute to Win It]]'' where the real-life Ralston was participating as a contestant playing for charity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/james-franco-gives-encouragement-aron-160981|title=James Franco Gives Encouragement to Aron Ralston on 'Minute to Win It' |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=March 4, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> After having an uncredited cameo in the opening scene of ''[[The Green Hornet (2011 film)|The Green Hornet]]'' (2011),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/01/13/2579741/the-green-hornet-is-swarmed-by.html |title=âThe Green Hornetâ has dull plot, lame humor |first=Robert W. |last=Butler |work=[[Kansas City Star]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |date=January 13, 2011 |accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref> he starred opposite [[Natalie Portman]] and [[Danny McBride (actor)|Danny McBride]] in the [[Medieval]] fantasy comedy ''[[Your Highness]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/filmNews/idUSTRE54T0L320090530|title=Natalie Portman signs on for comedy "Your Highness"|last=Kit|first=Borys|date=May 30, 2009|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|agency=Reuters |accessdate=June 1, 2009}}</ref> on April 8. In it he plays Fabious, a prince who teams up with his brother (McBride) to rescue Fabious' soon to be bride (played by [[Zooey Deschanel]]). In May 2010, he was cast to star in [[Rupert Wyatt]]'s $90 million budgeted ''[[Rise of the Planet of the Apes]]'', a [[reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the ''[[Planet of the Apes (franchise)|Planet of the Apes]]'' series<ref>{{cite news|first=Tatiana|last=Siegel|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118019653.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&ref=vertfilm|title=James Franco to star in 'Apes'|accessdate=May 23, 2010|date=May 20, 2010|work=Variety }}</ref> which was released on August 5. Franco has also announced that in the fall of 2011, he will appear on Broadway with [[Nicole Kidman]] in the upcoming revival of ''[[Sweet Bird of Youth]]'' by [[Tennessee Williams]], which will be directed by [[David Cromer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/Cromer_Says_Franco_Debut_in_SWEET_BIRD_OF_YOUTH_Likely_20110202|title=Cromer Says Franco Debut in SWEET BIRD OF YOUTH Likely|work=BroadwayWorld.com|date=February 2, 2011 |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> Franco will star alongside [[Winona Ryder]] in a film entitled ''The Stare'', which is to be directed by Jay Anania. Production is expected to begin in New York on May 6, 2011. He was cast as a drug-addicted lawyer in ''Cherry'', which will start shooting the following month in California and also star [[Heather Graham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118037296?refCatId=13 |title=Franco, Graham, Patel board indie 'Cherry' |first=Jeff |last=Snieder |work=Variety |publisher=Reed Business Information |date=May 18, 2011 |accessdate=May 19, 2011}}</ref> He dropped out of the indie ''While We're Young''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/archives/2011/03/06/noah_baumbachs_while_were_young_loses_james_franco_cate_blanchett_ben_still/# |first=Kevin |last= Jagernauth |title=Noah Baumbachâs âWhile Weâre Youngâ Loses James Franco & Cate Blanchett; Ben Stiller Still In |work=[[IndieWire]] |publisher=[[Snagfilms]] |date=March 6, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> to star in ''[[Oz: The Great and Powerful]]'', a [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]] prequel to [[L. Frank Baum]]'s ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz]]'' (1900), as the Wizard, superseding [[Johnny Depp]]. Filming began in July.
At the end of September 2010, the actor acquired the rights to [[Stephen Elliott (author)|Stephen Elliott]]'s ''The Adderall Diaries'', with the intentions to adapt, direct and star in it.<ref name="a.d.">{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/09/james-franco-buys-the-adderall-diaries/ |title=James Franco Buys 'The Adderall Diaries' |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=Mail.com Media Corporation |first=Mike |last=Fleming |date=September 29, 2010 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> It was announced in January 2011 that the actor has planned to not only star in but direct himself in ''The Night Stalker'', a film version of author [[Philip Carlo]]'s book about the 1980s serial killer, [[Richard Ramirez]]. Co-screenwriter to the screenplay, Nicholas Constantine, was initially unconvinced that Franco would be right for the movie, until he learned of Franco's desire to be a director and later watched three of his short films, one of which featured a serial killer, ultimately confirming to the writer that the actor had a darker side.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/16/james-franco-to-play-night-stalker-serial-killer-make-directorial-debut_n_809670.html |title=James Franco: 'The Night Stalker' Star And Director |work=Huffington Post |location=USA |publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc |date=January 16, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> One of his other upcoming projects, ''The Iceman'', will reunite Franco with [[Michael Shannon (actor)|Michael Shannon]], after the two worked together on the short film ''Herbert White''. The movie is based upon real-life contract murderer [[Richard Kuklinski]], who notoriously froze his victims.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/01/james_franco_and_michael_shann.html |title=James Franco and Michael Shannon Reunite for The Iceman |first=Kyle |last=Buchanan |work=[[New York Magazine]] |publisher=New York Media LLC |date=January 20, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> The actor also has plans to direct a film version of [[William Faulkner]]'s ''[[As I Lay Dying (novel)|As I Lay Dying]]''.<ref>Friedman, Devin. "Leading Man: James Franco." <u>GQ</u> Dec. 2010: 286â88</ref>
== Other projects == [[File:JamesFrancoOct10.jpg|thumb|left|Franco in October 2010|220px]] Franco produced and directed a documentary titled ''Saturday Night'' documenting a week in the production of an episode of ''SNL''.<ref>{{cite news|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/05/03/things-we-learned-about-saturday-night-live-from-james-francos-documentary/|title=Things We Learned About 'Saturday Night Live' From James Franco's Documentary|accessdate=July 30, 2010|date=May 3, 2010|work=The New York Times}}</ref> The film began as a [[short film|short]] for an NYU class but grew due to his two episodes as host, while short stories he wrote for other classes appeared in ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' and ''[[McSweeney's]]''.{{r|anderson20100725}} In summer 2010, the fictional Franco from ''General Hospital'' held an exhibit at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles|Museum of Contemporary Art]] in Los Angeles, while the real Franco held an exhibit at the museum based on his experiences on the soap opera.{{r|anderson20100725}}
One of his short movies, ''The Clerk's Tale'', was screened in competition at the Hamptons Film Festival at the end of 2010.<ref name="a.d."/> The short was also shown at the Cannes Festival. During an interview with [http://screencomment.com Screen Commentâs] Ali Naderzad, Franco had this to say about his Cannes experience: "Cannes is a huge honor. As a film student, having my short play on the closing night of Criticâs Week is the best thing I could ask for. The festival has honored so many of my favorite films and so many of my heroes, it is still hard to believe I will be involved with such an amazing festival. It is so nice to be recognized as a director."<ref>Naderzad, Ali (May 12, 2010), "[http://screencomment.com/2010/05/reading-between-the-lines-a-conversation-with-james-franco/ Reading between the Lines: James Franco on directing ''The Clerk's Tale'' and taking it to Cannes], ''Screen Comment''.</ref>
On October 19, 2010 [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]] published a collection of short stories called ''Palo Alto: Stories'' by Franco.<ref name="Palo Alto">{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/tonight/movies/a-life-in-constant-motion-1.1008128|title=A life in constant motion|publisher=iol.co.za|date=January 5, 2011}}</ref> The book is named after the California city where Franco grew up and is dedicated to many of the writers he worked with at [[Brooklyn College]]. Inspired by some of Franco's own teenage memories,<ref name="127facts">{{cite web |url=http://blog.moviefone.com/2010/11/02/james-franco-facts/ |title='127' Facts About James Franco |first=Kim |last=Potts |work=[[Moviefone]] |publisher=AOL Inc |date=November 2, 2010 |accessdate=March 30, 2011}}</ref> ''Palo Alto'' consists of life in Palo Alto as experienced by a series of teenagers who spend most of their time indulging in driving drunk, using drugs and taking part in unplanned acts of violence. Each passage is told by a young narrator.<ref name="t.g.article"/> The book has received mixed reviews; ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called it "the work of an ambitious young man who clearly loves to read, who has a good eye for detail, but who has spent way too much time on style and virtually none on substance."<ref name="Palo Alto"/> ''[[The Guardian]]'' said that Franco's "foray into the literary world may be met with cynicism in some quarters, but this is a promising debut from a most unlikely source."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2011/jan/02/palo-alto-james-franco-review|title=Palo Alto by James Franco â review|author=Killian Fox |work=The Guardian |location=UK|date=February 1, 2011}}</ref> Writing in the ''[[New York Times]]'', reviewer and fellow author [[Joshua Mohr]] praised Franco for how, in the story "American History", he juxtaposed historical parts with a present-day [[social commentary]] that "makes the we wonder how much weâve actually evolved in post-bellum America."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/24/books/review/Mohr-t.html |first=Joshua |last=Mohr |title=Teen Spirit, Soured |work=New York Times |date=October 22, 2010 |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
Publishers Weekly reviewed the collection, stating "The author fails to find anything remotely insightful to say in these 11 amazingly underwhelming stories."<ref>"Francowatch" The New York Observer.[http://www.observer.com/tag/francowatch/]</ref>
In January, the actor screened his multimedia project entitled ''Three's Company The Drama'', in which he merges video and art to update the former sitcom, at the [[2011 Sundance Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=12749711 |title=James Franco Talks 'Crazy Projects' at Sundance |work=[[ABC News]] |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |date=January 25, 2011 |first=Alicia |last=Rancilio |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> Franco reunited with ''Milk'' director Van Sant to make ''Unfinished'', a project that features two movies: ''Endless Idaho'' and ''My Own Private River''. ''Endless Idaho'' showcases edited outtakes, deleted scenes and behind-the-scenes footage from the 1991 movie ''[[My Own Private Idaho]]'', while ''My Own Private River'' focuses on the late actor [[River Phoenix]].<ref name="unfinsihed"/> The idea for the exhibition was conceived after Van Sant introduced unused footage from the 1991 film to Franco, inspiring him to turn it into something more. ''Unfinished'' opened from February 26 to April 9 at the [[Gagosian Gallery]] in Beverly Hills.<ref name="unfinsihed">{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2011/02/james-franco-gus-van-sant-exhibition-coming-this-week-to-gagosian-gallery.html |first=David |last=Ng |title=James Franco, Gus Van Sant exhibition coming this week to Gagosian Gallery |work=The Los Angeles Times |date=February 23, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref>
On February 27, 2011, he and [[Anne Hathaway (actress)|Anne Hathaway]] hosted the [[83rd Academy Awards]]. The two were selected to help the awards show achieve its goal of attracting a younger audience.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news |first=Susan |last=King |title=James Franco, Anne Hathaway to host Oscar telecast |date=November 29, 2010 |accessdate=November 29, 2010}}</ref> Franco had previously said that he accepted the job for the experience and because it was like a once in a lifetime opportunity.<ref>''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]''. December 2, 2010. [[ABC Studios]].</ref> Numerous media viewers criticized Franco for his discontent and lack of energy on stage and the show was widely panned, with some reviewers dubbing it the worst telecast in its history.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.myfoxphilly.com/dpp/entertainment/022811-critics%3A-oscars-were-historic-bomb |title=Critics: Oscars Were Historic Bomb|accessdate=February 29, 2011|date=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[WTXF-TV]]}}</ref><ref>{{citenews|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-563277?ref=feeds%2Foncnn|title=83rd Oscars Review: To Hip To Be Square?|author=TheVideoMan |publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc |publisher=CNN|date=February 28, 2011|accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110227/OSCARS/110229986 |title=Oscars: "King" wins, show loses |authorlink=Roger Ebert |last=Ebert |first=Roger |accessdate=February 28, 2011 |date=February 27, 2011 |work=Chicago Sun-Times |publisher=[[Sun-Times Media Group]]}}</ref> The actor later spoke about his hosting in an interview on ''[[The Late Show with David Letterman]]''. He explained that when accepting the job he never had high hopes, adding âIt was never on my list of things to do. It doesnât mean I didnât care and it doesnât mean I didnât try, right?â Regarding allegations that he was under the influence of marijuana while hosting, Franco commented "I think the [[Tasmanian Devil]] would look stoned standing next to Anne Hathaway. She has a lot of energy!" He concluded that he tried his best and could have had "low energy" during the telecast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20478170,00.html |title=James Franco & David Letterman Swap Oscar Horror Stories |first=Dahvi |last=Shira |work=People |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
In May, Franco made his dance-theater directorial debut at New York's Stella Adler studios, where he narrated all the performances. Entitled "Collage" and described as a "mixed-media piece", the show featured live dance, theater, music, and poetry. Tickets were free but were distributed on a first come, first serve basis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/04/james_franco_dance.html |title=James Franco to Mount Dance-Theater Show |author=Buchanan, Kyle |work=New York Magazine |date=April 29, 2011 |accessdate=April 30, 2011}}</ref> The actor will also direct two short films for songs ("Blue" and "That Someone Is You") by [[R.E.M.]] from their album ''[[Collapse Into Now]]'' (2011).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/various-artists/55253 |title=James Franco, Sam Taylor-Wood guest direct new REM videos |work=NME |location=UK |date=March 2, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref> Franco continued his career as a filmmaker with ''[[The Broken Tower (film)|The Broken Tower]]'', a 90-minute [[docudrama]] shot in black and white about poet [[Hart Crane]], who committed suicide by jumping off the steamship ''[[SS Orizaba]]''.<ref name="alotofinfo">{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/the_ticket/item/james_franco_q_a_his_film_on_tortured_gay_poet_hart_crane_20110615/ |title=James Franco Q & A: His Film on Tortured Gay Poet Hart Crane |first=Naomi |last=Pfefferman |publisher=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles]] |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=July 16, 2011}}</ref> It originally started out as his masters thesis.<ref name="nymag">{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/12/james_franco_on_playing_drunke.html|title=James Franco on Playing Sailor-Chasing Poet Hart Crane |work=[[New York Magazine]] |first=Mike |last=Vilensky |date=December 10, 2010 |accessdate=June 19, 2011}}</ref> After being screened at 2011's [[Los Angeles Film Festival]] {{endash}} among more than 200 feature films, short projects, and music videos from more than 30 countries to be selected<ref>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2011/05/los-angeles-film-festival-guillermo-del-toro-green-lantern-drive-james-franco.html |title=2011 Los Angeles Film Festival will welcome stars Guillermo del Toro, James Franco, Ryan Reynolds and more |first=Amy |last=Kaufman |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=May 11, 2011 |accessdate=July 16, 2011}}</ref>{{endash}}it is slated for a 2012 theatrical release.
== In the media == [[File:Jamesfranco.jpg|thumb|left|Franco being interviewed in 2011|220px]] He has been described as having "an unusually high metabolism for productivity...a superhuman ability to focus".{{r|anderson20100725}} Viewed as a [[sex symbol]], Franco was named the Sexiest Man Living in 2009 by [[Salon.com]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Sarah|last=Hepola|title=Sexiest Man Living 2009 |url=http://www.salon.com/entertainment/sexiest_man_living_2009/2009/11/19/james_franco/index.html|publisher=[[Salon.com]]|date=November 19, 2009|accessdate=November 20, 2009}}</ref>
There has often been frequent media coverage of Franco, particularly regarding his interest in going to colleges. In addition to that, Franco has also claimed to have been strongly misquoted by reports in the media<ref name="playboy"/> and news outlets reporting erroneous information about him.<ref>''[[Charlie Rose (talk show)|Charlie Rose]]'' [[Public Broadcasting System]] April 19, 2011.</ref> This led to the actor being parodied in an episode of ''SNL''{{'}}s Weekend Update segment, which an ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' writer deemed "clever".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://watching-tv.ew.com/2011/02/06/saturday-night-live-dana-carvey-linkin-park/ |title='Saturday Night Live' recap: Dana Carvey brought his old characters, some old friends, and Justin Bieber |work=Entrainment Weekly |publisher=Time Inc |first=Ken |last=Tucker |date=February 6, 2011 |accessdate=July 16, 2011}}</ref> In a 2011 interview, he stated:
<blockquote>"Iâve been perceived as this guy yelling, 'Hey, look at me. I want attention.' Iâm not going to school to get articles written about me. Iâm just going to school. But the fact that Iâm going to school or that someone takes a picture of me sleeping is like, 'Weâre gonna jump on that and criticize him for his antics.' What antics? I write. I make movies. Iâm going to school. I hosted the Oscars. I take these projects seriously."<ref name="playboy"/></blockquote>
In response to questions regarding his sexuality now that he has portrayed three gay characters during his acting career, he insists he finds plenty more dimensions to the characters than their bedroom proclivities. "Or, you know what," he quipped, "maybe Iâm just gay."<ref>{{cite news|first=Matt|last=Donnelly|title=James Franco's Maybe I'm just gay'- and why we love it|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/gossip/2011/01/james-franco-gay.html|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] blog|date=January 7, 2011|accessdate=January 8, 2011}}</ref> Those rumors led to a [[Gawker]] article linking him to a ''[[New York Post]]'' Page Six [[blind item]] about a [[closeted gay]] actor, nicknamed "the Gay Rapist". Despite the victim of the alleged attack denying that it was Franco, two magazines then contacted Franco's lawyer to alert them that they might run stories suggesting his involvement, but were unable to as at least part of their stories were fabricated.<ref name="playboy"/> However, Gawker refused to take their article down as they were simply reporting what another outlet published and instead offered him a chance to make a comment about the speculation on its website. He declined, hoping it would die down. The actor later called the episode very offensive because he has friends who have been raped.<ref name="playboy"/>
== Personal life == In 2008, he was named as the new face of [[Gucci]]'s men's fragrance line.<ref name="vanity f"/><ref>{{cite news|title=James Franco a big man in 'Milk' â and on campus|last=Pearlman|first=Cindy|date=November 30, 2008|work=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=December 2, 2008}}</ref> Regarding his secular upbringing, Franco told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that he feels as if he has "missed out on the Jewish experience", but has been told not to worry about that by his Jewish friends. He said in the same interview that he likes "the idea of religion as a source of community." When asked if he was a "believer", he responded "In God? I don't know. Yes. To a certain extent. It's a complicated question."<ref name=niadraug/> After meeting on the set of ''Whatever It Takes'', Franco dated co-star [[Marla Sokoloff]] for five years.<ref name="peoplebio"/> He was in a relationship with actress Ahna O'Reilly for several years since around 2006.<ref name="peoplebio">{{cite news |title=James Franco Biography|last=Dinh|first=Mai|coauthors=Janet Murphy|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=April 22, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-08-03-james-franco_N.htm|title='Pineapple' star Franco digs deep, plays stoner and serious|last=Freydkin|first=Donna|date=August 3, 2008|work=USA Today|accessdate=April 22, 2009}}</ref> He confirmed their separation in an interview for ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine's August 2011 issue, saying that his interest in education got between them.<ref name="playboy">{{cite web |url=http://www.playboy.com/magazine/james-franco-interview/2 |title=Playboy Interview: JAMES FRANCO |first=Stephen |last=Rebello |work=[[Playboy]] |date=July 11, 2011 |accessdate=July 16, 2011}</ref>
==Education== Dissatisfied with his career's direction,{{r|anderson20100725}} Franco reenrolled at [[UCLA]] in the fall of 2006 as an [[English studies|English]] major with a [[creative writing]] concentration. He received permission to take as many as 62 [[course credit]]s per [[academic quarter (year division)|quarter]] compared to the normal limit of 19,<ref name="schmelzer20100101">{{cite news|last=Schmelzer|first=Randi|title=Smart Set|url=http://magazine.ucla.edu/features/smart_set/|accessdate=September 6, 2010|newspaper=UCLA Magazine|date=January 1, 2009}}</ref> while still continuing to act. He received his undergraduate degree in June 2008 with a [[Academic grading in the United States#Grade point average|GPA]] over 3.5/4.0.{{r|schmelzer20100101}}{{r|anderson20100725}}<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2008/08/27/2008-08-27_brad_pitt_explores_other_options.html?page=1|title=Brad Pitt explores other options|last=Black|first=Rosemary|date=August 27, 2008|work=[[Daily News (New York)]]|page=2|accessdate=March 3, 2009}}</ref> For his degree, Franco prepared his departmental honors thesis as a novel under the supervision of [[Mona Simpson (novelist)|Mona Simpson]].{{r|anderson20100725}}<ref name=smartset>{{cite news | first=Randi| last=Schmelzer| url=http://www.magazine.ucla.edu/features/smart_set/| title=Smart Set| work=ucla.edu|work=UCLA Magazine Online|date=January 1, 2009|accessdate=January 15, 2010}}</ref> While at the university, the actor studied French, the [[Holocaust]], philosophy of science, and American literature among other things. To continue acting, he would study on film sets.<ref name=niadraug/>
He was selected as the commencement speaker at his alma mater, [[UCLA College of Letters and Science|UCLA]], and was to speak at the ceremony on June 12, 2009. On June 3, however, a press release announced Franco's cancellation due to a scheduling conflict, making it the second cancellation in a row, after commencement speaker [[Bill Clinton]] had canceled the appearance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailybruin.com/index.php/article/2009/06/franco-cancels-commencement-keynote|title=Franco cancels as commencement keynote|last=Schaefer|first=Samantha|date=June 3, 2009|work=[[Daily Bruin]]|accessdate=June 4, 2009}}</ref> On January 26, 2011, Franco and the Harvard Lampoon released a satirical video on prominent comedy website [[Funny or Die]] mocking his last-minute cancellation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/ab25302c8e/james-franco-s-rejected-ucla-commencement-speech/|title=James-Franco's-Rejected-UCLA-Commencement-Speech|date=July 8, 2009|work=[[Funny or Die]]|accessdate=July 8, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:James Franco Blue Angels.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Franco, just before he gets a ride in the [[Blue Angels]] No. 7, with Patrick Palma in a two-seat FA-18B, in August 2006]]
He moved to New York to simultaneously attend graduate school at [[Columbia University]]'s [[Columbia University School of the Arts#Writing|MFA writing program]], [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts]] for filmmaking,<ref name="vanity f">{{cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2008/12/franco200812|title=Franco cum Laude|last=Kamp|first=David|date=December 2008|work=Vanity Fair |accessdate=December 2, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2008/08/06/2008-08-06_side_dish_write_on_james_franco.html|title=Side Dish: Write on, James Franco|last=Evans|first=Sean |coauthors=[[Shallon Lester]] |date=August 6, 2008|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=September 21, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/09102008/gossip/pagesix/no_ogling__128375.htm|title=No Ogling!|last=Froelich|first=Paula|coauthors=Bill Hoffmann|date=September 10, 2008|work=New York Post|accessdate=September 21, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://gawker.com/374070/james-franco-to-sexify-morningside-heights|title=Academia: James Franco To Sexify Morningside Heights|publisher=[[Gawker.com]]|accessdate=September 21, 2008}}</ref> and [[Brooklyn College]] for fiction writing,{{r|schmelzer20100101}} while occasionally commuting to [[North Carolina]]'s [[Warren Wilson College]] for poetry.{{r|anderson20100725}} He received his MFA from Columbia in 2010.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/29/james-franco-yale_n_517769.html James Franco To Get Yet Another Degree At Yale?<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Franco is a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] student in English at [[Yale University]]<ref>{{cite web|first=Esther|last=Zuckerman|url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/crosscampus/2010/03/28/now-he-can-fall-asleep-lc-too/|title=Now He Can Fall Asleep in LC Too|accessdate=March 31, 2010|date=March 28, 2010|work=[[Yale Daily News]]}}</ref> and will also attend the [[Rhode Island School of Design]].{{r|anderson20100725}} The actor opted against watching the 2011 Academy Award nominees be announced (where he was a top contender) in favor of attending class. "Iâm not gonna miss class to go and presume that Iâm going to be nominated, but if you want to bring out a camera crew to Yale and wait and see if I get nominated, Iâd be happy to step out of class and say Iâm very grateful", he commented.<ref>{{cite news |title=James Franco puts school before awards |work=Daily Telegraph |date=January 25, 2011 |accessdate=April 29, 2011}}</ref>
He has been accepted to the [[University of Houston]] for the doctoral programâone of 20 people to be selected out of 400 applicantsâin literature and [[University of Houston Creative Writing Program|creative writing]] and plans to enroll in fall 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/life/main/7531811.html|title=Actor James Franco accepted to UH creative writing program|date=April 21, 2011|work=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=April 21, 2011}}</ref> Having previously shown a desire to teach, in March 2011, it was announced that Franco will teach a fall semester course on modifying poetry into short films to ten to twelve third-year graduate film students at NYU. The course will focus mainly on production, meaning that the students will be in charge of creating their own film based on poetry. At the time of the announcement the actor had yet to put together a syllabus, but has until the summertime to do so.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/03/29/james-franco-nyu-course/ |first=Keith |last=Staskiewicz |title=James Franco to teach film course at NYU, but no syllabus as of yet |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=March 29, 2011 |accessdate=April 23, 2011}}</ref>
When asked about his education, Franco said that he loves school and that it keeps him focused as well as grounded. "I go to school because I love being around people who are interested in what Iâm interested in and Iâm having a great experienceâ¦ Iâm studying things that I love so itâs not like itâs a chore", he told the ''[[Washington Post]]'', according to a ''[[New York Magazine]]'' article.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/05/james_franco_to_teach_yale_stu.html |title=James Franco to Teach Yale Students |work=New York Magazine |author=Duboff, Josh |date=March 3, 2010 |accessdate=April 29, 2011}}</ref> Franco has also credited his education for helping him "take acting seriously" when his parents did not see it as a successful post-college career.<ref name="itas"/> Franco developed an aptitude for artâpainting in particularâduring his high school years while attending the [[California State Summer School for the Arts]] (CSSSA).<ref name="Yahoo"/> Franco has said painting was the "outlet" he needed in high school, and he "has actually been painting longer than he has been acting."<ref name="painting">{{cite web | title=Lindzi.com Your Connection to the Stars | work=James Franco | url=http://www.lindzi.com/interviews/james.htm | accessdate=February 1, 2007}}</ref> His paintings were displayed publicly for the first time at the [[GlÃ¼ Gallery]] in Los Angeles, from January 7, through February 11, 2006.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite news|first=Ann|last=Oldenburg|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/2002-08-14-celebs-painting_x.htm|title=Celebrities pour passion into artwork|accessdate=August 8, 2008|date=August 14, 2002|work=USA Today}}</ref> He launched his first European art exhibition in 2011 at Peres Projects in Berlin.<ref name="t.g.article">{{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/2011/feb/20/james-franco-art-oscars-interview |title=The many lives of James Franco |first=Helen |last=Pidd |work=The Guardian |date=February 20, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref>
He enjoys reading on the set of his films. ''Pineapple Express'' producer [[Judd Apatow]] has said of him: "He's a very education-minded person. We used to laugh because in between takes he'd be reading ''[[Iliad|The Iliad]]'' on set. We still haven't read ''The Iliad''. It was a very difficult book. With him, it was always [[James Joyce]] or something."<ref name="USAToday">{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-08-03-james-franco_N.htm|title='Pineapple' star Franco digs deep, plays stoner and serious|last=Freydkin|first=Donna|work=USA Today|date=August 5, 2008|accessdate=January 3, 2011}}</ref>
== Charitable work == Franco has said aiding others is "the key to life, the key to happiness" and, "as an actor, you can get wrapped up in yourself and your career...A little secret is one of the greatest ways to break that is to stop thinking about yourself for a second."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2010-12-08/entertainment/27083812_1_actors-studio-james-lipton-james-franco |title=James Franco credits obsession, UCLA education, giving back for success: 'Inside the Actors Studio' |work=NY Daily News |author=Chen, Joyce |date=December 8, 2010 |accessdate=April 29, 2011}}</ref> When Franco was at a point in his life where he wanted to give back but was unsure how, he asked his ''Spider-Man'' co-star [[Kirsten Dunst]] for advice. At the suggestion of Dunst, he started volunteering at the charity Art of Elysium, where she also volunteers, which helps children with serious medical conditions. He said the experience helped save his life. In January 2011, at the Art of Elysium Heaven Gala in Los Angeles, Franco was honored for his work at the hospital, receiving the Spirit of Elysium accolade.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.azcentral.com/ent/celeb/articles/2011/01/17/20110117james-franco-kirsten-dunst-charity-advice.html |title=James Franco saved by Kirsten Dunst's charity advice |work=[[The Arizona Republic]] |date=January 17, 2011 |accessdate=April 13, 2011}}</ref>
On March 31, 2011, the actor took part in "An Evening with James Franco", a Washington DC dinner benefit for 826DC, a non-profit foundation created to help neighborhood students reach their goals, as well as provide after-school literature programs and workshops which encourage them to improve their writing skills. Franco became involved with Dave Eggers' [[826 National]] after Eggers asked him to do a conceptual idea for the program, and he directed a documentary for them and has since been a supporter of them. At the event, Franco spoke about how he thought schools needed to be more original with their literature programs. "Writing can do things that video cannot", he added.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonlife.com/2011/04/04/charity-spotlight-evening-with-james-franco/ |title=Charity Spotlight: Evening With James Franco |publisher=Washington Life Magazine |date=April 4, 2011 |author=Farazad, Roshan |accessdate=April 13, 2011}}</ref>
In April, Franco autographed a T-shirt that will be auctioned-off through the Yoshiki Foundation, with the proceeds being donated for the [[2011 TÅhoku earthquake and tsunami|Japanese tsunami relief]] occurring in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hollywoodcrush.mtv.com/2011/04/13/robert-pattinson-japan-relief/ |first=Jocelyn |last=Vena |title=Robert Pattinson Takes Off Shirt For Japan Relief |publisher=MTV |publisher=Viacom |date=April 13, 2011 |accessdate=April 13, 2011}}</ref> On June 14, he was honored by [[amfAR]], the foundation for [[AIDS research]], at the [[Museum of Modern Art]]. Franco received the Piaget Award of Inspiration for his humanitarian work and contributions to menâs style.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2011/05/31/James_Franco_Honored_by_amfAR/ |title=James Franco Honored by amfAR |work=[[The Advocate]] |publisher=Here Media Inc |date=May 31, 2011 |accessdate=May 31, 2011}}</ref>
